parts:
Hi DR. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record tool, year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build a markdown **fenced code block** CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find. Do not include any inline citations automatically generated by the deep research process (i.e., AI-generated or system-injected references i.e. 【deep research】 or ​:contentReference[oaicite). 

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand the requirements clearly. Please provide the name or acronym of the first archaeology or historical studies-related software tool you'd like me to research.

Understood. I will conduct a thorough search for mentions of the software tool **Sériation de matrice en présence/absence**, ensuring that every relevant source is captured systematically. I will provide a well-formed quoted CSV with details on the tool, year, source, URL, and any relevant AI notes regarding data provenance or quality.

I will let you know once the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a thorough search for mentions of the software tool **Sériation de matrice en présence/absence**, ensuring that every relevant source is captured systematically. I will provide a well-formed quoted CSV with details on the tool, year, source, URL, and any relevant AI notes regarding data provenance or quality.

I will let you know once the research is complete.","title":"Evidence Collection for Sériation de Matrice en Présence/Absence","prompt":"Conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the software tool **Sériation de matrice en présence/absence** in archaeology or historical studies, ensuring that every relevant source is captured systematically. 

For each valid source, construct a well-formed quoted CSV containing the following columns:
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes".

- **Tool**: Maintain consistency in the name as given.
- **Year**: Use the publication year from the source. If no date is available, mark it as "n.d.". Do not infer years—only record explicitly stated years.
- **Source**: Provide a citation or use the format (Domain + Page Title).
- **URL**: Include the exact link to the resource.
- **AI Notes**: Indicate any concerns, uncertainties, or data provenance issues found during research.

### Research Guidelines:
1. **Explore all search results carefully**, visiting all relevant pages, repositories, and literature databases.
2. **Expand searches** ±1 year around any identified date to ensure comprehensiveness.
3. **Allowed sources**:
   - Published version control repositories (public codebases with commit history)
   - Scholarly literature (each mention to be included as a row)
   - Blog posts and tool about pages
   - Any other verifiable mentions of the tool
4. **Do not include AI-generated citations** (e.g., system-generated references or fabricated sources).
5. **Record each unique source separately**, even if multiple sources mention the same tool.

Provide the results as a **fenced code block CSV** in markdown format with each row corresponding to a unique mention of the tool. 

Let me know if additional clarification is needed."}

metadata.async_task_title: Evidence Collection for Sériation de Matrice en Présence/Absence
metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of the software tool **Sériation de matrice en présence/absence** in archaeology or historical studies, ensuring that every relevant source is captured systematically. 

For each valid source, construct a well-formed quoted CSV containing the following columns:
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes".

- **Tool**: Maintain consistency in the name as given.
- **Year**: Use the publication year from the source. If no date is available, mark it as "n.d.". Do not infer years—only record explicitly stated years.
- **Source**: Provide a citation or use the format (Domain + Page Title).
- **URL**: Include the exact link to the resource.
- **AI Notes**: Indicate any concerns, uncertainties, or data provenance issues found during research.

### Research Guidelines:
1. **Explore all search results carefully**, visiting all relevant pages, repositories, and literature databases.
2. **Expand searches** ±1 year around any identified date to ensure comprehensiveness.
3. **Allowed sources**:
   - Published version control repositories (public codebases with commit history)
   - Scholarly literature (each mention to be included as a row)
   - Blog posts and tool about pages
   - Any other verifiable mentions of the tool
4. **Do not include AI-generated citations** (e.g., system-generated references or fabricated sources).
5. **Record each unique source separately**, even if multiple sources mention the same tool.

Provide the results as a **fenced code block CSV** in markdown format with each row corresponding to a unique mention of the tool. 

Let me know if additional clarification is needed.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Evidence Collection for Sériation de Matrice en Présence/Absence

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"Sériation de matrice en présence/absence","n.d.","open-archaeo (Sériation de matrice en présence/absence)","https://open-archaeo.info/post/s%C3%A9riation-de-matrice-en-pr%C3%A9sence-absence/","No publication date provided; open-archaeo listing describes this Excel macro-based seriation tool (author: Bruno Desachy)【1†L93-L99】."
"Sériation de matrice en présence/absence","n.d.","GitHub (open-archaeo software list)","https://github.com/zackbatist/open-archaeo","Listed in the open-archaeo repository of open-source archaeological tools (no date given)【25†L1943-L1949】."
"Sériation de matrice en présence/absence","2024","ArchéoFab Hypotheses (SESAM – seriation presence-absence)","https://abp.hypotheses.org/5505","Bruno Desachy's blog post introducing the 'SESAM' tool – an Excel spreadsheet for presence/absence seriation【33†L222-L230】."
"Sériation de matrice en présence/absence","2016","ArchéoFab Hypotheses (Explographe 1.0 – LibreOffice Calc seriation tool)","https://abp.hypotheses.org/5413","Mentioned as 'SESAM sériation de matrice en présence/absence' under related tools【4†L251-L258】; included for context (the page's main focus is a different tool)."
"Sériation de matrice en présence/absence","2021","Publications de l’École française de Rome (Musarna 4, Chapitre 8)","https://books.openedition.org/efr/10243","Used as a chronological seriation method for fine pottery; described as an automated spreadsheet developed by B. Desachy【8†L155-L162】."
```

metadata.title: Sériation de matrice en présence/absence • open-archaeo
metadata.text: Excel file containing macro commands making it possible to transform a 1/0 table (presence / absence) into a graphic matrix treated by matrix permutations; it is possible to take into account the uncertain presence of a character. The instructions for use are contained in the file.

metadata.title: GitHub - zackbatist/open-archaeo: A list of open source archaeological software and resources
metadata.text: * Sériation de matrice en présence/absence: Excel file containing macro commands making it possible to transform a 1/0 table (presence / absence) into a graphic matrix treated by matrix permutations; it is possible to take into account the uncertain presence of a character. The instructions for use are contained in the file. * by: Bruno Desachy * links: Website

metadata.title: SESAM – SEriation Semi Automatique par les Moyennes réciproques pour les tableaux de présence-absence – ArchéoFab – Archéologies du Bassin Parisien
metadata.text: par  Bruno Desachy · Publié 08/06/2024 · Mis à jour 27/11/2024

metadata.title: Explographe 1.0 – application de traitement graphique de tableaux de données sous LibreOffice Calc – ArchéoFab – Archéologies du Bassin Parisien
metadata.text: archive ZIP contenant le fichier Seriographe sous Excel, son mode d’emploi, un article exposant les principes (RAP 2004), et deux exemples commentés dans l’article

metadata.title:
Musarna 4 -
                                                                            Chapitre 8 -
                                                Publications de l’École française de Rome
metadata.text: traitement informatique. Aujourd’hui, l’accès à cet outil est facilité par la mise à disposition d’un fichier automatisé de tableur développé par B. Desachy5 . Dans le cadre du projet AchéoFab qu’il dirige, les recherches ont continué de multiplier les approches statistiques et le traitement de données réalisé à partir de tableaux de comptage 34. À partir de ces travaux, nous avons choisi d’utiliser le tableur de sériation de matrice en présence/absence7, qui est apparue comme le plus adapté à l’étude des céramiques à paroi fine de Musarna.
